overview: Beginning 1/1/2026, this measure requires pharmacy technicians to be registered with the Board of Pharmacy. [4] It imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians and specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. [4] This amended version adds a definition for "auxiliary pharmacy personnel" for personnel whose duties are clerical in nature and clarifies the duties of registered pharmacy technicians. [4]
appropriations: This measure does not appropriate any funds. [3] The registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt). [3] Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than $100.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [3]
assumptions_and_methodology: The provided legislative documents do not contain any specific assumptions or cost estimation methods. [3] Financial projections are based on the fee and fine amounts established in the bill. [3] [3] Testimony states that "This initiative comes at a reasonable cost and represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce." [2]
agency_impact: The board of pharmacy is responsible for issuing certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians. [3] The board may also fine, suspend, or revoke any registration or permit for any cause prescribed by this chapter. [3] Furthermore, the board shall adopt rules to define the functions of pharmacy interns and the employment of registered pharmacy technicians. [3] [3]
economic_impact: This measure will have an economic impact on individuals working as pharmacy technicians, who will be required to pay a registration fee of $20.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt). [3] There is also a potential economic impact from fines, as any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than $100.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [3] Testimony supports the measure, stating that Hawaii is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians. [4]
policy_impact: This measure amends Chapter 461, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by adding a new section to require the registration of pharmacy technicians beginning January 1, 2026. [3] It adds new definitions for "Auxiliary pharmacy personnel," "Registered pharmacy technician," and "Supervision" to clarify roles within a pharmacy. [3] The definition of "Registered pharmacy technician" now explicitly excludes pharmacy interns and auxiliary pharmacy personnel. [3]
revenue_sources: Revenue to support this measure will be generated from a registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [3] The registration fee shall be $20.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt). [3] Additional revenue may be generated from fines, as any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than $100.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [3]
six_year_fiscal_implications: Beginning January 1, 2026, this measure will generate revenue for the state through a registration fee for pharmacy technicians of $20.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt). [3] Since each registration shall be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year, this will create a recurring biennial revenue stream. [3] Additional potential revenue may be generated from fines for violations, which range from $100.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt) to $1,000.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt). [3] The provided documents do not include projections on the number of pharmacy technicians who will register. [3] There is no information regarding necessary staffing changes or other recurring expenses related to the administration of this registration program. [3] Therefore, a detailed six-year fiscal projection cannot be accurately calculated based on the available information. [3] The initial revenues from registration would be collected for the biennium ending December 31, 2027. [3] The bill does not outline any plans for program expansion. [3] Testimony indicates that as the roles of pharmacy technicians expand, it is vital to ensure these workers meet a baseline level of competency. [2] All proceedings for denial, suspension, or revocation of a registration shall be conducted pursuant to chapter 91, which may have associated administrative costs. [3]
operating_revenue_impact: This measure will have a positive impact on operating revenues. [3] The State will collect a registration fee for a pharmacy technician of $20.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt), which is renewable biennially. [3] Additional, non-recurring revenue may be collected from fines of not less than $100.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt) nor more than $1,000.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [3]
capital_expenditure_impact: The provided legislative documents do not indicate any capital expenditures related to this measure. [3] No investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure are mentioned. [3] The measure focuses on registration and regulation, not capital improvements. [3]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The fiscal implications after six years will consist of ongoing biennial revenue from the collection of the pharmacy technician registration fee of $20.00 (HB72_HD1_.HTM.txt). [3] Since each registration shall be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year, the fee collection is a recurring event. [3] The provided documents do not contain information regarding the long-term sustainability of this funding or the projected number of registered technicians. [3]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: This amended version of the measure adds a definition of "auxiliary pharmacy personnel" for personnel with clerical duties, excluding them from the definition of "pharmacy technician". [4] It also clarifies the duties of registered pharmacy technicians and what constitutes supervision by a registered pharmacist. [4] A significant change is the effective date, which has been moved to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [4] Additionally, language regarding continuing education requirements for license renewal has been removed. [3]
fte_positions: The provided legislative documents do not specify the addition or modification of any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions. [3] There is no mention of new roles required to administer the registration program. [3] The bill does not address staffing changes. [3]
appropriations_changes: No appropriations were specified in the previous version, and none are included in this version. [3] The bill establishes fees and fines rather than allocating funds. [3] [3] Therefore, there are no changes to report. [3]
funding_sources_changes: The method of funding remains consistent with the previous version. [3] [3] Revenue will be generated from a registration fee and potential fines. [3] [3] No changes in funding sources, such as shifts between general and special funds, are included in this bill. [3]
department_impact: The bill's impact remains on the board of pharmacy, which is tasked with the new regulatory responsibilities. [3] There has been no change in the department responsible for expending appropriations or implementing the measure. [3] The bill does not shift responsibilities from one department to another. [3]
reports_required: The reporting requirements have not changed. [3] A pharmacist-in-charge is required to notify the board in writing within ten days if a registered pharmacy technician is suspected of violating any law or regulation. [3] If any danger to the public health or safety exists, the notification must be made immediately. [3]
pilot_program: This bill does not create a pilot program. [3] It establishes a permanent registration requirement for pharmacy technicians. [4] The bill does allow the board to approve pilot and demonstration research projects for innovative applications in the practice of pharmacy, but the registration itself is not a pilot. [3]
sunset_date: The provided legislative documents for HB72 HD1 do not contain a sunset date for the program or the bill. [3] The registration requirement for pharmacy technicians is intended to be permanent. [3]
effective_date: The effective date for this measure has been changed from the previous version. [4] This Act shall take effect on July 1, 3000. [3]
